text: English grammar lesson 20 topic compound
words formed from phrasal verbs watch
and listen do you know the difference
between showing and showing off I'll try
to explain I'd like to show you my fan
collection it's not very big but it's
special to me I have four white fans
that look like this pretty and I have
two black fans that look like that these
black fans are very comfortable to hold
they're very pretty but of course
they're even more beautiful when you put
them into motion now I'd like to show
you my favorite fan in the collection
this was a gift it's a fan from Japan
it's beautiful I like looking at it
almost as much as I like using it but of
course when we use it you can really
admire the beauty I remember most of the
tricks I used to do with this fan one
idea that was showing off just a little
bit so before you start thinking of me
it's a truth show up we're going to talk
about compound words formed from phrasal
verbs
let's first make the difference clear
between showing and showing off show is
a verb and as you know it means to let
someone see something for example I want
to show you my fan collection do you
want to see it show off is a phrasal
verb we have the verb show and the
particle off when we put these two parts
together we have a new definition to act
in a way so that people will admire you
or to try and win people's respect for
what you have or what you can do for
example Jennifer was showing off with
her fans she thinks people will find her
dance moves interesting all right now
that we're clear about that difference
let's move on let's look at this
sentence please don't think I'm a
show-off is this an example of a phrasal
verb well you've probably noticed that
in this sentence showoff is written with
a hyphen also it follows an article what
kind of a word follows an article not a
verb a noun here we have an example of a
compound word more specifically a
compound noun it's a compound noun
formed from a phrasal verb let's talk
more in detail about what compound words
are a compound word is a noun or
adjective formed from two or more words
compound words are often formed from
phrasal verbs especially two-word
phrasal verbs and by that I mean a verb
with one particle as in show off by
joining this verb and it's one particle
with a hyphen we get the compound noun
show off compound words formed from
phrasal verbs are written with the - as
in show off or as one word as a workout
let me share a couple study tips some
compound words formed from phrasal verbs
are very common but not all phrasal
verbs form compound words for that
reason avoid trying to create a new one
before checking a dictionary be sure the
compound word exists before you use it
also a dictionary will confirm whether a
compound word formed from a phrasal verb
is written as one word or with a hyphen
so if you're not certain how to write a
compound word check the dictionary it's
time again to watch and listen
do you work out I know I need to
exercise more my last workout was one or
two weeks ago most of this workout
equipment that you see belongs to my
husband let's be clear about the
difference between workout and workout
written as two words workout is a
phrasal verb as you know it means to
exercise for example my husband works
out a lot so he's strong and healthy
written as one word workout is a
compound word this compound word can be
either a noun or an adjective look at
our two examples
Jennifer's last workout was one or two
weeks ago Jennifer's husband uses
different kinds of workout equipment
let's turn our attention to
pronunciation do you hear a difference
in pronunciation a difference between
compound words and phrasal verbs which
words are stressed listen closely as I
say these three sentences one do you
work out - my last workout was one or
two weeks ago three this is my husband's
workout equipment you've probably noted
that we stress the beginning of a
compound word that is formed from a
phrasal verb listen as I say three
compound words please don't think I'm a
show-off
my last workout was one or two weeks ago
this is my husband's workout equipment
now I'd like to compare the stress and
phrasal verbs and the stress and
compound words listen and repeat after
me she sometimes shows off
she's a show-off he often works out his
workouts are usually 30 minutes long if
you have the opportunity to record your
own voice I'd suggest doing that when
you play it back make sure you hear the
difference in stress patterns exercise 1
in this exercise your task is to do
three things first read the statement
and identify the meaning of the phrasal
verb then state the compound word we can
form from that phrasal verb and finally
contrast the stress patterns of the
phrasal verb and the compound word it's
a lot to remember so let's try an
example together example Gary's car
broke down again the mechanic said it
would take one or two days to fix the
car what does breakdown mean a drive
slow B get old or C stop working well
I've given you a clue with the picture
break down means seize stop working we
use break down when we're talking about
cars or machines so now that we know
what this phrasal verb means let's go on
to the next step if a car breaks down on
the highway there is often a special
lane on the far side of the road for the
driver to pull into this keeps the car
out of the way for passing drivers what
do you think we call this lane what
compound word can be formed from the
phrasal verb breakdown written as one
word breakdown is the compound and that
special lane for emergency use it's a
breakdown lane now listen and repeat if
your car breaks down pull over into the
breakdown lane now I'd like you to try
number one the child looked out the
window with excitement as the plane took
off soon she could only see clouds
what does takeoff mean a rise off the
ground B land on the ground or C come to
a stop the answer a rise off the ground
all right we know when a plane takes off
it rises off the ground and flies into
the air but what do you think we call
this event what compound word can be
formed from the phrasal verb takeoff
written as one word the compound is
takeoff listen and repeat we sat in the
airport and watch the plane's take off
the man had never flown before so he was
a little nervous during takeoff
to the company was losing business so
the management decided to lay off
hundreds of employees their workforce
decreased by 25%
what does layoffs mean a give work to be
stopped employing or c.replace layoffs
means B stop employing when a company
lays people off it stops employing them
because there isn't enough work for
everyone what do you think we call this
event what compound word can be formed
from the phrasal verb layoffs written as
one word layoff is the event I have seen
it written with a hyphen
but I prefer one word now listen and
repeat the company will lay off a
quarter of its employees the economic
crisis has led to many layoffs in the
United States
three getting sick set me back in my
work I may not meet my deadline
what does setback mean a help
development B make progress slow or C
confuse the phrasal verb setback means B
make progress slow
when a problem sets you back it makes
your progress slow so what do you think
we call this experience what compound
word can be formed from the phrasal verb
sent back written as one word set back
is what a person can experience it's a
compound noun now listen and repeat
the builders arrived late work on the
house was set back a few days there was
a small fire on the construction site
but that was a minor setback they'll
soon be on schedule again
there's more I'd like to tell you some
compound words formed from phrasal verbs
do not use the structure base verb +
particle as in show-off and workout
instead their structure is past
participle + particle the past
participle as you'll recall is the third
form of a verb for example eat ate eaten
do did done so let's look at examples of
these compound words that use the
structure past participle + particle
I'll give two examples grow-up is a
phrasal verb and you likely know it
means to become an adult now read with
me Marissa is no longer a child
she's a grown-up she's 20 years old you
see a - joining the past participle
grown and the particle up this forms a
compound noun a grown-up you've already
seen the phrasal verb break down we know
it means to stop working now I'd like to
show you a second compound word formed
from this phrasal verb read with me it
was obvious that no one had lived on the
farm for a long time the barn was empty
and there was a broken-down tractor in
the fields again we have a - joining a
past participle and a particle we have a
compound adjective broken-down describes
something it tells us that something is
in bad condition or can't be operated
anymore a broken-down tractor here's an
important pronunciation note compound
words which are formed from phrasal
verbs and which use the form past
participle + particle can have different
stress patterns a dictionary will help
confirm the word stress of a compound
word examples 1 grown-up sons and
daughters stress is at the beginning
grown-up
to a broken-down tractor both parts are
stressed but the second receives more
stress a broken-down tractor exercise to
watch and listen pay attention to the
pronunciation of the compound words my
family is getting ready to celebrate
Christmas we're going to have a small
get-together with our friends so I've
prepared some gifts
I have toys for the children and small
little gifts for the grown-ups my
children don't expect to get their
Christmas presents until the very
morning of December 25th and that's
because they still don't know that the
tale of Santa Claus is a made-up story
their Christmas presents are actually
hidden upstairs under our bed and I've
asked my husband what are we going to do
if the children discover their presents
before the 25th so our cover-up story is
that this year Santa has so many
children to visit he's asked us if he
could deliver the presents early
well I know that sounds silly but
they're still small so we want our
children to believe in the Christmas
magic a little bit longer
[Music]
additional practice for this lesson is
available at English cafe comm my user
name is Jennifer ESL follow the direct
link listed in the video description
[Music]
that's all for now thanks for watching
and happy studies into all those who
will be celebrating Christmas of
December 25th I send you my warmest
wishes Merry Christmas
